results.title: The Bass Valley Community Centre
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Clare Le Serve started a craft group for young mums in the early 1980s, she could not have imagined that it would grow over the next 30 years to become such an amazing community asset. With the help of local volunteers and paid staff, the Community Centre offers essential services that make a positive impact on the people of Bass and the surrounding Waterline region in south-eastern Victoria.
results.description: When Clare Le Serve started a craft group for young mums in the early 1980s, she could not have imagined that it would grow over the next 30 years to become such an amazing community asset. results.title: The Corinella Jetty
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 2005, the small waterline community of Corinella in south eastern Victoria, was at risk of losing its iconic jetty. Barbara Oates, a local and owner of the general store, rallied the community to raise $10,000 to have the jetty renovated and extended, ensuring the prominent landmark would be enjoyed for generations to come.

results.title: Following their footsteps
results.brief_description: The small towns of Kernot and Grantville in south-eastern Victoria, depend on volunteer emergency services to ensure that when fires break out, car accidents happen or cats are stuck in trees, that someone is there to help. Who better to have on call than local legend Barrie Stewart and the dedicated members of the Kernot/Grantville CFA.

results.title: Community banking Bass Coast
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Early in 2001, the banks pulled out of the small coastal town of San Remo in south eastern Victoria, leaving the community with a challenge. Rather than sit on his hands and accept the inevitable consequences of downsizing, a local hardware store owner, Terry Ashenden, pulled together a committee of residents and business owners to overcome the problem.
results.description: Early in 2001, the banks pulled out of the small coastal town of San Remo in south eastern Victoria, leaving the community with a challenge. Rather than sit on his hands and accept the inevitable consequences of downsizing, a local hardware store owner, Terry Ashenden, pulled together a committee of residents and business owners to overcome the problem.

results.title: DAK: David Alexander Kopelman
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: yDAK doesn’t consider himself an artist, he just “dabbles and makes stuff”. Despite this his scrap-metal sculptures and decorative gates can be found throughout the neighbourhoods, businesses and galleries of the Bass Coast in south-eastern Victoria. Cape Woolamai’s very own mo-hawked road warrior has a plasma cutter and he’s not afraid to use it!

Despite this his scrap-metal sculptures and decorative gates can be found throughout the neighbourhoods, businesses and galleries of the Bass Coast in south-eastern Victoria. results.title: Life in the waves: a story about Island Surfboards
results.brief_description:
Sandy Ryan’s life revolves around surfing, helping his dad run ‘Island Surfboards’ on Phillip Island in south-eastern Victoria, and teaching others how to ride waves. Matt’s best mate and mentor, Glyndyn, is an ex-pro surfer that shapes boards for ‘Island Surfboards’ and doesn’t mind a surf either.
This is a story about a mateship, keeping it local and living the surfing lifestyle dream.

This is a story about a mateship, keeping it local and living the surfing lifestyle dream.

results.title: The Gasifier
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bill Gardner is tackling climate change in his own backyard, with the help of his mates John and Will. Together, these ‘Wimmera men’, located in western Victoria, are investigating the potential of using gasifier technology, which can be used to convert grain into fuel. Rather than being dismissed as ‘crazy’, this initiative has received widespread support from both the government and community.

results.title: Gil and Liz Hopkins
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Gil and Liz Hopkins have lived in Laharum, in western Victoria, for over 30 years. They raised three children there, built their own home, which is nearly completely self-sufficient, with solar panels and reclaimed water. Their hope is to leave the land in better shape than they found it and they’re taking their knowledge to the community to help others do the same.

results.title: An Olive Grove in Laharum
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Toscana Olive Plantation and Laharum Grove, in western Victoria, both operate from the same original plantation of olives, working together to ensure the freshness, quality and flavour of their oil. While they acknowledge Laharum is a peaceful place to live, the workers at these olive farms are hectic, determined to produce some of the best quality olive oil in Victoria.
results.description: Toscana Olive Plantation and Laharum Grove, in western Victoria, both operate from the same original plantation of olives, working together to ensure the freshness, quality and flavour of their oil. results.title: Clarrie's Ranch
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Jessica Scott, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Clarence ‘Clarrie’ Mackley has built his own patch of paradise, a small ranch devoted to Slim Dusty, Elvis and all things country and western. Living by his ethos of ‘do what you wanna do’, Mackley attracts tourists from all over to the world to his colourful place in Horsham, western Victoria.
